page.title: 01The Slopes of Pennard Hill
page.content: Pennard Hill is an outlier of midle lias formed by land slippage after Glaciation. This well drained land slopes southwards over about 2Km from 100m above sea level to 30-40m, where there is a flat plain of lower lias clay. This is wetland needing artificial drainage. Grass is abundant, so that dairy farming with sheep grazing is the main occupation. there are apple orchards east Pennard with its 15th Century church is the historic focus for the Hamlets of Hembridge and Huxham Green and th scattered farms. With the loss since 1960's of school, postoffice and resident rector the inhabitants must look outside the area of amenities. The hamlet of Parbrook is also without amenities. The trunk road A37 (Roman Fosse way) cuts across the south East of the area. Local roads are narrow.
